participants.participant: Helen A. Weir CBE, Group Finance Director
J. Eric Daniels, Group Chief Executive

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning and welcome to the Lloyds TSB Full Year Results Presentation for 2007. With me up here on the platform are Eric Daniels, the Group Chief Executive and Helen Weir, our Group Finance Director and they'll both be making some prepared comments after me, following which we will open the ... open up the floor to questions.

I am particularly pleased to be standing here today presenting these results. Firstly because as you know, 2007 was a really good year in terms of both our operating and our financial performance and this notwithstanding the turbulent backdrop of recent times and events.
But more importantly this set of results is part of a continuing journey over the last four years or so which has transformed this company into the strong and growing organization that it is today.

Whereas I'm pleased, I perhaps understate what I really feel. I take great pride in our performance as a company. Yes, profit before tax of 3.9 billion is a great underlying financial performance. But there are so many other achievements of this Group that don't necessarily always get there due credit.

Our position is number one in current account ... in the current account market, in personal loans, in new business start-ups and home insurance and so on, our high scores around customer service and customer advocacy, with our key focus around wanting to help our customers to succeed financially.

The industry recognition that we receive for products and services that we provide. I mean, just to pick a couple: most trusted banking in Britain, for the seventh year running; corporate bank of the year, for the third year running; best individual pensions provider, and the list goes on.

I am proud of the achievement and the commitment of our employees. Not just to Lloyds TSB itself, but their commitment and involvement in their communities through, for example, the work they have done both for and with

Our work around social responsibility partly, through the Lloyds TSB Foundations, who give away over £37 million each year, one of the largest corporate donors in the country and reinforced by our work in the community supporting the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games.

And last, but by no means least, our work around Climate Change, and where we set out ourselves stretchy targets for reducing our CO2 emissions, a 30% reduction by 2012, and the commitment which we have achieved to be carbon neutral through the purchase of credits in 2007.

This sort of performance and these achievements do not happen by accident, and they're a credit to the strategic vision and leadership of Eric Daniels and his management team. That's what they have brought to Lloyds TSB.

Today, we have a strong and sustainable business built around the lower risk, low volatility business model. It's one which continues to thrive and grow due to deep-set relationships that we have with our customers, based on the products and services that meet their everyday financial needs. And whilst we're likely to see a slowing of the UK economy during 2008, we're confident that our business model cannot just withstand the downturn, but continue to grow. In many respects, these are the conditions that will prove the strength of the model that we have created. For these reasons, the Board of Lloyds TSB has decided to increase dividend for the year by 5% to 35.9p per share. And going forward, we expect to continue to grow the dividend over time whilst also growing dividend cover.
And on that positive note, let me hand you over to Helen who will take you through the numbers.

Thanks Victor and good morning everyone. This morning I'm pleased to be presenting another strong set of results, which once again demonstrate the momentum we've established in our business. Notwithstanding the relatively limited impact of the market dislocation, we've delivered a very good performance.

On a strategy basis, earnings per share were up by 17% and economic profit up by 21%. These figures include the significant disposal gains made on the sales on non-core businesses. To get a better sense of the underlying momentum in our business, it's more appropriate to discuss the trends excluding the impact of these disposals, and other one-off items including the settlement of overdraft claims and last year's pension scheme credit.

On this basis, profit before tax is up by 6%, with earnings per share and economic profit growth of 8% and 9% respectively. Our return on equity is also increased slightly from an already high base. Overall income growth of 5%, despite the impact of market dislocation, demonstrates the good progress we're making in delivering our relationship strategies across our businesses.

At the same time, we've continued to maintain strong cost control, with group expenses up by only 1%, giving a robust set of positive jaws. This, combined with our strong top-line performance, means that our trading surplus grew strongly, up 9%.

Impairments were up year-on-year in part as a result of the market dislocation, with the result that profit before tax grew by 6%. However, included in these figures is a 280 million charge relating to the market dislocation in W&IB. Adjusting for this to get a better picture of the Group's operational performance during 2007 would result in strong double-digit profit growth with revenue up by 6% and profit before tax up by 13%. And this is after a charge of more than £100 million in respect to flood-related claims.

We've made fundamental improvements to the business in the last three to four years, and the results are evident on each line of the P&L. Firstly, the good income growth is a result of our focus on building customer relationships and gaining greater share of our customer's wallets. This shows first in our sales figures and then in income. The good news here is that we are building annuity-like income flows, evidenced by the strong flow in liabilities. In addition our margin is improving.

On costs, we continue to focus on sustainable cost reduction that then creates headroom for further investment in the business. Our productivity program has once again delivered benefits ahead of target. And we remain well on track to deliver net benefits of £250 million in 2008, even after reinvestment.

Our asset quality remains satisfactory. We've actually seen an improvement in the quality of the book reflecting the relatively conservative nature of our business model. Alongside this, we've continued our work on capital efficiency and on transition to Basel II, we'll actually see an increase in our Tier 1 ratio and a stable capital ratio. Last, the robustness of our model including our strong customer deposit base, has meant that we've continued to fund very successfully during the recent market turmoil.

Turning now to the drivers of income growth. Firstly, balance sheet growth. In retail, asset growth was 6% driven primarily by mortgage balances, while unsecured retail lending was broadly flat in a slightly declining market.

We've seen very good growth on the liability side of the balance sheet and our savings growth has been particularly strong. Retail deposits increased by 8%, including strong growth in bank savings, which were up 15% and wealth management, up 12%. In the last six months alone, retail savings balances were up by over £4 billion. In the wholesale bank, we saw a strong performance with particularly good asset growth in commercial banking, and in corporate markets where our strong liquidity position has allowed us to continue to lend to good quality customers throughout the more challenging conditions in recent months.

Liability growth was also robust, with customer deposits up 18%. There was strong deposit growth in commercial across a range of products, especially fixed interest saving accounts, as well as good growth in large corporates and also in our international businesses. So our focus on continuing to build strong customer relationships is delivering good growth on both sides of the balance sheet.

Turning now to margin. This is a slide I've used a number of times. The key difference this time, however, is that we've actually seen an improvement in margins in the second half of 2007 compared with the first half. Over the last year or so, we've talked of total product margins being broadly stable, and the decline in margin being driven by mix. While this picture is true for the year as a whole, in the second half some product margins began to increase and more than offset the mix effect. In particular, margins have widened in the corporate book and margins on mortgage allocations have improved. Although the benefit of this will primarily be seen in 2008, as allocations in the pipeline are drawn down.

Turning to the individual divisions and looking specifically now at the drivers of income growth in the retail bank. This is now a familiar picture. Once again we've seen the liability side of the balance sheet making the greatest contribution to overall income growth. And this is important in terms of income sustainability because liability-led earnings tend to be recurring.

We continue to make good progress in driving income from both savings and investments. Our focus has been very much on growing bank savings deposits, where we've been encouraging our customers to save regularly. Similarly, we've been focused on growing our wealth deposit book, and have increased the number of customers in our investment portfolio who also bank with us.

These relationship balances are the more profitable areas of our savings book, and are also important from a liquidity perspective, because they tend to be more sticky. We've also seen good growth in AVA fees as a result of both strong sales and higher fee levels. And last year we opened almost half a million new or upgraded AVA accounts.

On the asset side, we saw continued income growth from lending, and an increase in commissions from insurance products reflecting improved pricing to risk and an increase in the proportion of sales through the branch network.

Turning now to the wholesale division, where if we exclude for the moment the revenue impact of market dislocation, income is up 6% year-on-year. Most of this growth came from two key relationship businesses – Corporate Markets and Commercial Banking – while asset finance income was impacted by the slowdown in the unsecured consumer credit market and tightened credit criteria.

Commercial Banking income, increased by 8% as a result of continued strong lending and deposit balance growth driven by new-to-bank recruitment. In addition, we saw very strong growth in cross-group business generation. For example, Scottish Widows product sales to commercial customers, and a new product, such as fixed rate deposits in credit cards.

In Corporate Markets, we've continued to develop our business with core -... with our core corporate customer base. This long-term relationship strategy, as well as the development of new product capabilities, has enabled us to deliver very strong growth in cross-selling income up nearly 35% during the year.

Lloyds' development capital growth for the full year was up by nearly 50%; albeit the unusual level of realizations reflect at the half-year returned to a more normal level in the second half. Clearly, no bank can be immune from the significant turbulence in global financial markets over the last six months or so. However, Lloyd TSB's limited exposures in the key areas of contagion mean that we've relatively very well positioned.

In our news release, we've endeavored to be as transparent as possible and split the impact of market dislocation into its different components. The overall impact on our product to market's P&L is limited to £280 million. The first point to note is we've no direct exposure to U.S. subprime ABS.

We've broken out our CDOs held as part of our structuring business. In terms of the unhedged positions, all the junior tranches are effectively fully written-down, and the limited residual exposure amounts to some 130 million relating to super-senior high-grade notes, which have a 2005 vintage and with no underlying asset defaults.

We also have a holding of CDO super-senior notes, which is fully hedged with a CDS from a triple rated -- a AAA rated monoline. The gross value of the position stands £470 million after we have taken £25 million write-down against the CDS protection. At the end of the year, the reliance placed on this swap was £155 million.

In addition, we've approximately 1.9 billion of CDOs hedged by leading financial institutions with any exposure fully cash collateralized. The risk here is, therefore, effectively global bank counterparty risk.

With limited SIV Capital note holdings, all of these SIVs are fully funded, although the costs of funding have clearly increased. This, combined with some uncertainty of the future funding has led us to take a provision of £22 million against these holdings.
In addition, we had a further 370 million of SIV liquidity backstops of which 98 million were drawn at year end. These are senior facilities, and there's no reason to believe that they're impaired.

We've also provided details of the impact on our trading portfolio. We're aware that not every bank has done this, but we wanted ensure that we provided full disclosure. We've seen mark-to-market falls in parts of our trading book, which reflects the market wide re-pricing of liquidity into a lesser extend credit.

Our greatest write-down, at £92 million, is in the ABS book, while we've written down our secondary loan trading book, which consists entirely of performing corporate loans by £20 million. The remaining £32 million represents a variety of small mark-to-market adjustments against high-quality assets, primarily, high-quality senior European and U.S. bank bonds and investment-grade corporates. We're confident in the underlying quality of these assets and expect the recovery in values as and when the market returns to a more normal state.

In addition, we've seen a write-down through reserves of just over 400 million in our AFS book. Over half of this relates to the ABS assets held in Cancara, our conduit. At the end of the year, all the ABS bonds in Cancara were AAA rated, although since then about £70 million of the 8.3 billion portfolio's been downgraded. Since its inception in 2002, there's never been a default on any asset in Cancara. In addition, there's no exposure either directly or indirectly to subprime U.S. mortgages, and only very limited Alt-A exposure. Throughout the credit crunch, Cancara is continued to fund well and at market leading rates.

The remaining AFS write-downs are split broadly between U.S. Government-backed Student Loans and major bank senior paper, as well as high quality ABS, of which more than 95% are AAA rated. These AFS assets are intended to be held until maturity, and under IFRS are marked-to-market through reserves. The assets are not impaired, and we expect to obtain full value from them on maturity.

So, overall, as we have said before, one, no financial institution is left unaffected by the recent market dislocation. Our prudent business model has meant that the impact on the group is relatively low.

Turning to Insurance and Investments, where we again saw good growth. On an EEV basis, Scottish Widows profits were up 6% or 11% after adjusting for surplus capital repatriation. New business sales were up 7%, with sales through the more profitable bank insurance channel up 20%. Contributing to this was the strong growth in protection sales, including the new protection for life product, and also the insourcing the manufacturing of an existing product.

Sales through the IFA channel increased by 2%, against record eight day related sales in 2006. Retirement income products and corporate pensions grew strongly, more than offsetting a reduction in savings and investments sales, where we choose to focus on margin and not chase uneconomic business.

The new business margin remains strong by industry standards at 3.1%, but was lower than last year's, as a result of the in source protection product and a higher discount rate. Existing business profit remained robust with overall lapse experienced in line with the expectations. Weaker persistency in life and pensions was broadly offset by a favorable experience in the OEICs business. And the expected return on shareholder funds increased as a result of the higher levels of free assets and higher returns.

As well as growth, return is an important metric throughout the Group. This is reflected in the continued improvement in capital efficiency at Scottish Widows. Through, for example, the introduction of an OEIC-backed savings product replacing a more capital intensive life bond.

As a result, despite a 7% increase in new business sales, less capital was required to support new business volumes. This, in addition to the regulatory changes introduced in late 2006, resulted in significant improvement in new business capital efficiency. Improved capital efficiency, combined with the capital repatriation program, means that our return on embedded value has again increased and stands at 9.9%. We expect this level to improve further in 2008 as a result of the full year impact of the disposal of Abbey Life, which was a relatively low returning business.

Turning now to costs. As you'd expect, tight cost management continues to be a priority for us. All our divisions have once again delivered a strong cost performance, notwithstanding the continued investments we are making in the business. All our divisions have also once again delivered income growth ahead of cost growth. As a result, our cost income ratio continues to improve and now stands at 49%, down almost 2 percentage points on last year.
Turning to impairment, the group charge for impairment losses grew by 15% or 8% excluding the impact of the corporation tax rate change and market dislocation.

In the retail bank, we've indicated earlier in the year that we didn't expect that retail impairment charge to be any higher in 2007 than in 2006, and our expectations have been realized with the charge actually falling by 1%, and an improved AQR.

The quality of new unsecured lending continues to be strong, and we've seen lower levels of customer insolvencies, improvements in the group's collections procedures, and a reduced level of retail arrears. In particular, mortgage arrears are down year-on-year.

Over the last few reporting periods, I've used the dynamic delinquency charts to demonstrate the quality of our new business. I've decided to retire these charts, or this set of results, although they are included in the back of your packs. Suffice to say, they show the same patterns as previously, that recent lending in both our loans and cards books continues to perform well.
In wholesale, as expected, the underlying impairment charge increased, reflecting a lower level of releases and recoveries, growth in the book and a couple of specific charges in the corporate book.

Impairments in assets finance followed a similar trend to the retail book falling slightly year-on-year. Asset quality in the SME book continues to be strong, reflecting in part our strategy of focusing on secured lending. So, overall, asset quality in the wholesale remains good.

In the past year, there have been some questions about our property lending, particularly given the recent growth in the book. So, I thought it will be helpful to give you some facts which will indicate why we're confident in the quality of our portfolio.

At year-end, the lending to property companies amounted to £17.6 billion, or about 18% of our overall wholesale lending. Growth in the second half slowed to £1.5 billion. The portfolio split's approximately one-third residential and two-thirds commercial property.

Of the residential lending, over half is to local authority-backed public housing. Within the commercial property portfolio, over 90% is investment or corporate credit lending. Development lending is less than 10% of the portfolio and is subject to strict lending criteria. We require that the interest expense is fully covered by pre-let income and that the overall level of lending does not amount more than 60% of the gross development value.

We're relatively underweight in the office in retail sectors, and our geographic spread is consistent with the market as a whole, although, we don't have any office lending in either the City or Canary Wharf. Our loan-to-value on the commercial portfolio as a whole is around 62%. So, I hope this information goes some way towards providing you with some background and context as to why we are so confident in the property portfolio we've built up.

You may have already seen the new IFRS 7 asset quality disclosures in this morning's announcement. The first point is ... to make is that the quality of the book remains very strong with over 97% of our assets classified is unimpaired. However, the new disclosures enable us to look one level lower by portfolio.

On this basis you can see that the quality has actually improved since last year, with the percentage of our assets classified as either good or satisfactory quality increasing in two out of our three portfolios. And in the third, mortgages, it's already very high.

There's been a great deal written about the potential for a slowdown in the UK, and the knock on impact on impairments. So, I thought it will be a good time to pause for thought and reflect on some key factors that are tied to our impairment outlook.

In terms of the economy as a whole, interest rates are a downward trend, and our employment levels remain at a relatively low level. In addition, levels of corporate liquidity remain strong. At the same time in our own book, the quality of new business remains good, arrears levels are falling and our underwriting and collections procedures continue to improve.

So, whilst the economic outlook remains uncertain, many of the current lead indicators are good. As a result, we don't expect to see a significant change in the retail impairment charge in first half of 2008 compared with the first half of 2007.

I've already spoken about the good income and profit momentum in the business. However, this growth has not come at the expensive returns. Our return on equity is high and stable, and during the year, we increased both the return on risk weighted assets and economic profit. Note that these figures include the impact of the market dislocation. So although the economic profit growth is not quite double-digit, I think it reflects very well on the underlying performance of the business.

Moving on to our capital ratios. Growth in group risk weighted assets was 10%, much of which is accounted for by wholesale, where RWAs grew by 14% with an increase of only 4% in the retail bank, reflecting growth in the mortgage portfolio.

Going forward, we expect high single-digit or low double-digit annual growth in RWAs, reflecting increased customer lending opportunities. We've repatriated a further £1.9 billion in capital from Scottish Widows during 2007, making a total of over £3.6 billion in the last three years. Overall our capital position remains strong. Our capital ratios are robust and we continue to have significant capital headroom.

At the beginning of 2008, we successfully transitioned to Basel II. This new regime impacts both regulatory capital as well as the calculation of risk-weighted assets. The chart shows the impact on our capital ratios, if we'd been operating under Basel II at the year end, so effectively our 2008 opening capital ratios. As you can see, the net effect on the Group is a significant increase in our Tier 1 ratio, while our total capital ratio remains unchanged.

There are a number of factors behind this. Firstly the risk weightings used under Basel II reflect much more closely the underlying risks associated with our assets. And we've seen a reduction in our risk weightings, particularly in the mortgage book and in our corporate business. Offsetting this is the deduction for expected losses, which at this point in the cycle are actually above our actual provisions. And the disallowance of collectively assessed provisions which were included under Basel I. So, overall our total capital ratio is unchanged, while our Tier 1 increased by 1.4 percentage points.

Before I finish, I would like to touch on the liquidity position of the Group. Throughout the crisis, we've continued to fund well, and at market leading rates. There are a number of factors behind this. I have already mentioned not just the absolute size, but the growth that we've seen in our customer deposit base. As a result, we have a conservative wholesale funding profile. Our strong funding position is evidenced by our AAA Moody's credit rating, which was reaffirmed only last month.

A final factor has been the consistent market presence that we've maintained through the recent months, leveraging our long-term relationships. And we ensured that all times we have significant headroom over our short-term funding needs. The recent liquidity crisis has been another situation which our relationship model has proved itself. One of the key reasons for our strong profile is our high and growing customer funding base.

We currently over ... have over £156 billion of customer deposits, the majority of which are sticky relationship deposits. This includes over £46 billion of current account balances. As a result of the strength of our relationship customer funding base, our overall wholesale funding requirement is significantly lower than that of our peers.
Net net, all this translates into a funding advantage for the bank, such that during the recent period of market turbulence, our funding operations continued to fund on a business as usual basis.

As you can see from the chart on the left, our short-term funding level has remained relatively consistent, even slightly down over the last six months, notwithstanding the credit crunch. And our cost of money market funding has remained broadly unchanged from a year ago. Looking at longer-term funding, using UK bank five year senior CDS spreads as a proxy for funding costs, you can see that in June last year there was very little difference between spreads of the four major UK banks on this chart. By December, while spreads had widened for everyone, Lloyds TSB CDS remained significantly lower than that of our peers.
Spreads have moved even further out now, but our advantages remained. Our prudent business model and the strength of our customer deposit base, means that we have a demonstrable funding advantage.

In summery then, 2007 has been a year of considerable delivery, as we've continued to build momentum, notwithstanding the challenging market conditions. We've delivered a strong set of figures and continue to build earnings momentum in a high quality balanced set of businesses. Cost management remains strong, and we've again delivered wide positive jaws.

Our focus on improving efficiency means that we've once again substantially improved our cost-income ratio. Asset quality remains satisfactory, and we continue to demonstrate that we can both grow the business and maintain our high returns. Finally, we have a robust capital position, having successfully transition to Basel II, and we continued to improve our capital efficiency.

All this has created an increased confidence in the Group's ability to sustain good momentum, a confidence that's reflected in the Board's decision to increase the dividend, and endorse a progressive dividend policy going forward.
With that, I'd like to handover to Eric, who will take you through a further overview of our progress.

Thanks very much Helen. Good morning and thank you very much for coming. Over the next few minutes I would like to update you on our strategic progress for the year and give you some context around our results, as well as to what to expect as we look forward.

2007 has been a good year for the group, despite the challenges coming from the credit markets in the second half of the year. We've shown good progress across the group in furthering our strategy and virtually every front.

We cannot ignore the 280 million we took in losses from the market dislocation. It clearly impacted our results. However, if you look at the charge in relationship to the Group's balance sheet and profit and loss account, it is manageable and reflective of our more conservative business model.

We are facing into more uncertain markets than we have seen for some time, but that said, we have solid underpinnings and good momentum. To get a better view of our performance for the year and what's really going on in the business as well as our prospects for the future, it's more appropriate to look at our core business results.

All my subsequent slides will talk to business performance and exclude the market dislocation impact. All three divisions are growing. We have good income growth, positive jaws, good growth in profit before tax.

We believe we have significant potential for growth and a substantial track record of accomplishment that gives us the confidence that we can realize that potential. We think that 2007 demonstrates that we're producing good growth and high quality earnings that will be sustainable even with lower economic growth and a more uncertain environment.

Our core income, excluding the market dislocation impact, grew by 6% in 2006. We've shown sustained momentum over the past five years. The growth in income is high quality and based on building relationships, and reflects another strong year of growth in sales and gains in market share.

The results are broad based. We saw good progress in each division. Income rose 6% in the retail bank, 6% in the wholesale bank, and 7% in the insurance division. As Helen showed you, we worked every line of our P&L effectively.

In addition to broadly based income growth, we had good jaws and well controlled impairments. PBT as a result increased 13%, again excluding the impact of the market dislocation, continuing the good trajectory that we've established over the past several years.

As you know the guiding principal for the group has been to deliver double-digit economic profit growth on a consistent basis. With the strong profit before tax and the rigorous management of capital, we delivered a 20% growth in economic profit for the year. Our expectation is that our current momentum, which is based on solid fundamentals, will allow us to continue to drive future profit growth.

Our future growth will in some measure depend on what happens in the market, but in a much greater measure to our ability to be able to grow share. Looking first at the market: this is a good market to be in. It's the second largest economic profit pool in the world after the U.S. And the economic profit pool will continue to grow over the medium-term.

UK households have the greatest financial wealth of the major countries in Europe, and the UK has the lowest unemployment rate amongst the G7. Within the market, we expect to see strong growth in long-term savings, as Britain's demographics change, which plays well to our strengths in customer, distribution and product. We think the UK market remains an attractive one over the medium-term.

The second and most important driver of our future profit growth is our ability to capture share within the market. We do not see any near term limits to growth. We currently have only about a 10% share of the economic profit pool for financial services, and we believe we can enhance that participation, as we only have about one-third of our customers' wallets today.

We are gaining new customers at record rates, and we're deepening relationships, such that we are gaining share across a broad spectrum. Our relationship-focused business model has driven growth over the past few periods and will continue to do so.

We fundamentally believe that our business is about efficiently acquiring customers and serving their full set of financial needs over their lifetimes. We believe our relationship model leads to higher quality income, as much of the revenue stream is recurring. Having the relationship allows us the opportunity to cross-sell against additional customer needs.

The relationship focus also leads to lower costs, as incremental sales to existing customers are more targeted, more effective and far less costly. We don't have to acquire a new customer in order to sale a product.

Our relationship approach also leads to better controlled risk. We know our customers well, and we are better able to assess their capacity for credit. When we designed the model, we consciously set our risk parameters with a view to losses through the cycle. If you believe relationships are over a life ... over a lifetime are the key driver to your business, it serves you well to help your customers manage their credit position.

As our strategy is less subject to cyclicality and has more stable earnings, this translates into lower volatility, and therefore lower capital requirements. The result of the relationship strategy is sustained profitability and growth.

Let me now turn to the divisions and talk about the quality and sustainability of earnings, and why we will continue to deliver over the next several periods. Turning first to the retail bank, we've moved to ... the franchise to a strong relationship focus over the past several years. As you can see from the chart only 15% of our earnings are product driven, principally IFA introduced business, and some non-franchise card sales.

Importantly, if you look over the past two years, relationship driven revenues have increased by 11% whereas product driven revenues have improved by 2%. The UKRB is a terrific franchise and the great majority of the revenue and our future growth comes from relationship selling.

A critical part of the approach is managing customer information. In the retail bank, we have 18 million customer records, and we see 16 million transactions a day. That give us over 2,000 data points for each customer and, as evidence by independent benchmarking, we are rated top quartile in our customer relationship capabilities. The data is now well-integrated into our sales processes, and allows us to sell to customer need and price to risk on an individual basis.

Additionally, our data provides us critical early warning indicators about individual customers, as well as broader behavioral trends. By way of example, in the third quarter of 2007, we noticed a change in our customers' behaviors as they were spending more on food and less on clothing. This was an excellent indicator of a more cautious consumer and a shift in consumption patterns. We used our data to tune our lending policies and to change the sale force emphasis.

Let me give you an example of how we use customer understanding to grow the business. Two years ago we identified a modest shift in consumer behavior away from consumption and toward more concern for savings. The slide on the left is what I showed you in February of '06. The heat map identified areas where we expect to see stronger income growth from consumer demands, such as savings and investments, from the over 45 year olds.

We focused on the opportunity, renewed the products set and improved the sales process. As you can see from the chart on the right, we had a 16% growth in liabilities over the two year period. We also managed lending growth effectively, flexing our scorecards to reflect the environment and this supported the improvement in impairments.

We have the best single brand distribution network in the UK and in recent periods, we've shown how we can systematically use it to grow share as we've developed the skills to acquire and deepen relationships.

We're building market leading positions. We're the number one in terms of the acquiring new current accounts and new credit card issuance. And we're number one in terms of both flow and stock for added value accounts, home insurance and personal loans. We're continuing to grow our sales volumes, which rose 17% during the year to record highs.

One of the things we watched carefully is the new current account sales as they are the key to relationship banking. In 2007, we opened over 1 million new current accounts, a fantastic achievement by Terri and her team. We're improving our ability to cross-sell ... to sell more products to customers at the initial account opening. We're currently selling 1.2 additional products on average for new-to-bank customers, up from half a product two years ago.

We've shown that we can successfully acquire customers and to cross-sell them. Despite having made considerable progress, we know we have significant opportunity within the franchise. Of our customers who use a savings account, only 50% of them have them with us. Of our customers who have a mortgage, only 25% of them have them with us. The potential of the existing franchise is significant, and it will continue to grow as we capture new customers.

As I mentioned before, we run lower risks as our lending is principally to the franchises customers. In mortgages, we sell a higher percentage of loans to customers than any other major lender. We avoid the more extreme areas in the market and we focus on profitability rather than share. We have very good loan-to-value ratios with 63% on new business and 44% on the book overall. We do not offer self-certification mortgages and never have. As a result, our three month arrears actually fell during the year, down 12% and we have deminimus impairments.

The unsecured portfolio is also performing well. The major emphasis again is on franchise lending where we use our superior customer understanding. 99% of personal loans and 89% of cards are sold through to franchise customers.

During 2007, we saw falling arrears in impairments as our portfolio held up well. Wholesale and international, in our case, is also fundamentally a relationship business. We derive 70% of our profit from relationships. Over the past two years the income from relationships has grown more than three times as fast as that of products. In commercial banking, one of our key relationship franchises where we look after customers with the turnover of up to £15 million, we've seen further strategic progress. Truett and his team have put in place a platform to grow. We're experiencing record customer satisfaction in combination with strong product offers. We have leading share of start-ups and we are a net gainer in terms of attracting more valuable switcher accounts.
